Bug.Summery: [Dialogs] 'Advanced' button not always displayed in dialog to create folder

Lines.Line: 1. Choose a project
2. Right click of project and select project's properties
3. Select "Java Build Path" in left navigation tree
4. Select "Source" tab in right pane
5. Click "Add Folder...". New dialog "Source Folder Selection" will appear
6. Click "Create New Folder". New dialog "New Folder" will appear
with "Advanced >>>" button
7. Enter some folder name and click "OK"
8. Repeat steps 5 - 7. Dialog "New Folder" will appear without "Advanced >>"
button

Bug.WithStack:
Hi guys,
I found that if I try to assign some external folder to be a Java folder for my project and use functionality "Add Folder ..." in java build path tab of project's proprty dialog and after that click "Create New Folder ..." then I can see the button "Advanced" on the pop up dialog. If only I select some external folder and click again the button "Create New Folder ..." then the button "Advanced" is not shown. Of course it's not bif deal, just a liitle nuisance.
Cheers, Andrei It always appears for me. Can you describe more clearly the steps you used? Billy,
The bug appears in 3.0.1 as well. You need to perform this sequence of actions to see it: 1. Choose a project 2. Right click of project and select project's properties 3. Select "Java Build Path" in left navigation tree 4. Select "Source" tab in right pane 5. Click "Add Folder...". New dialog "Source Folder Selection" will appear 6. Click "Create New Folder". New dialog "New Folder" will appear with "Advanced >>>" button 7. Enter some folder name and click "OK" 8. Repeat steps 5 - 7. Dialog "New Folder" will appear without "Advanced >>" button
Cheers, Andrei
This message is part of a mass update on bugs that have been reviewed for several releases, but not fixed. The bug is legitimate, but not a priority. Marking P5. Patches would be entertained. As per http://wiki.eclipse.org/Platform_UI/Bug_Triage_Change_2009

If only I select some external folder and click again the button "Create New Folder ..." then the button "Advanced" is not shown. Of course it's not bif deal, just a liitle nuisance.

Bug.Summery: Eclipse dialogs not sized correctly under XFCE

Lines.Line: - attempting to resize the dialog causes the dialog to move rather than resize
- When this happens, the dialog always appears to open at the right width to make the title fit nicely.

Bug.WithStack:
Hi, I have this problem ever since I upgraded to Eclipse 3.0. The dialog boxes (especially the delete confirmation) are sometimes ( 1 in 3) incorrect size. The dialog box cuts off the text.
I have an LFS 5.0 system running 2.6.5. Attached should be 2 images showing one good, and the other bad.
Saad. Created attachment 12941 Delete Problem Created attachment 12942 Good Image. Just an update... I switched from XFCE 4.0.5 to the newest CVS (First of all.. it ROCKS).. Second.. Eclipse still isn't fixed... :( Are you using the Motif or GTK version of Eclipse? What other plugins do you have installed on top of the base Eclipse SDK? Hi There, I'm using GTK and the only other plugin I *recently* installed is the Tomcat plugin. But it was still rendering sizes incorrectly before.
Just to clarify a little bit, the problem isn't only with the delete dialog. Almost all popup dialog get incorrectly sized @ one point or another.
Saad. Is it an interaction with the window manager? For some reason I think this problem is only with XFCE Window Manager. The reason is because I got azureus (torrent client) and it also uses SWT and it also sometimes incorrectly renders dialogs.
I tried both of the applications in twm and there is no problem what so ever... yet..
Saad. I was investigating a similar issue with Enlightenment in bug 77267. The problem is likely that the GTK+ method gdk_window_get_frame_extents() is not returning correct information under this window manager. This problem should go away in 3.1RC3 and newer due to the fix for bug 99527. Can you test with this release? If so I will mark this bug as a duplicate. I'm convinced this is a duplicate. Please re-open if you can reproduce with eclipse 3.1.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 99527 *** Created attachment 31034 another screenshot
another screenshot. it's much the same as the first one, tbh :) I'm afraid I'm still seeing this on 3.1.1.
Things I've noticed which may or may not be relevant:
- attempting to resize the dialog causes the dialog to move rather than resize - When this happens, the dialog always appears to open at the right width to make the title fit nicely.
For all I know, this may be an XFCE bug, but I've not seen it anywhere else.
I'm using xfce 4.2.2 Sorry, the case you're seeing is actually bug 100659 which is finally (and this time for real) fixed for 3.2M4 and newer.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 100659 *** (In reply to comment #13) > Sorry, the case you're seeing is actually bug 100659 which is finally > (and this time for real) fixed for 3.2M4 and newer. > So it is. Yay. Thanks. :)

Bug.Summery: SWT RowLayout: It's unclear what is the function of the Row Option 'Fill' is.
Bug.WithStack:
Create a new empty visual class in the Java class which has the SWT library added. Drop a Shell on to the canvas followed by a number of SWT components. Bring up the Customize Layout dialog, and on the Row Options 'Fill', 'Pack' and 'Wrap' would be on by default (i.e True). However, when Fill is the only option ON, it appears to perform no function - either with the row orientation is set to vertical or horizontal. But when Pack is true as well, some functionality can be then attributed to Fill. This just makes the function of the option very unclear. Jeff... please provide an explanation According to the javadoc for Row Layout, pack specifies whether all components should be given their default size. Fill specifies that all controls should have the same height/width (depending on the row orientation) Fill isn't on by default.
I just fooled with it a bit and it seems like if pack isn't specified, all the components are given the largest size possible such that each component is the same height and width.
I don't know if it's the role of these customization pages to explain the functions provided by the various options on the layout. Perhaps we could include the javadoc explanation on the hover help in the next release. Since this bug was not reOpened for more than a month, this bug is verified. now closing.

Bug.Summery: [Workbench] [EditorMgmt] Usage of the Middle-click
Bug.WithStack:
The Middle-click diesn't seem to be used at all in eclipse 3.0. For instance, It would be nice to be able to close an editor with a Middle-click in the editor tab. Do you mean on Windows XP? Middle-click has a special meaning on Linux, and most Mac machines only have one mouse button. Yes on Windows. I forgot it had a special meaning on unixes, sorry. I just thought of it when I tried to close an editor with a middle-click ( which is the way I close tabbed browsers in Firefox). I really think it would be a nice feature to have, it's a lot quicker to click anywhere on the tab to close an editor than to point and click on the cross icon: it doesn't require as much precision. Changing Platform and OS to correspond with comment #1 and comment #2. I'd recommend against doing this, as it doesn't seem to be native behaviour on Windows XP, and seems to require special functionality for Windows-only.
What does Firefox do on Linux then? Firefox 0.8 on Linux does not seem to respond to middle-click on a tab. ... and neither does Firefox 0.9 on Linux. This seems non-standard based on the comments following the original. There are however other options such as Ctrl+W from the keyboard.
*** Bug 71422 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** *** Bug 91841 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** (In reply to comment #6) > This seems non-standard based on the comments following the original.
I did not find any closeable tabs in bare Windows XP to determine whether that's "standard" or not.
IMO, Eclipse should also support this useful feature (and offer a preference for those who don't like it). Let's follow the path of other successful "tabbed browsing" applications! > > This seems non-standard based on the comments following the original. > > I did not find any closeable tabs in bare Windows XP to determine whether that's > "standard" or not.
Now it has become standard even in IE7 (in addition to Firefox, Opera, ...). I would also very much like to see this feature implemented for the Windows version of Eclipse, as I find myself automatically trying to middle-click close tabs in eclipse. I believe the feature is standard in a lot of programs with tabs, the Trillian chat program comes to mind, in addition to the already mentioned Firefox, IE7, and Opera web browsers.
I have just discoverred there is actually already a plugin which does this, but I think it is something which deserves to be done natively within eclipse.
For anyone that wants to get the plugin for this, it can be found here: http://www.hlsoft.com/clickclosestab_eclipse Looks like this has been implemented for I20071127-0800. (In reply to comment #12) > Looks like this has been implemented for I20071127-0800.
Yes indeed. Btw, I didn't realize that Firefox (2.0) on Linux does not support middle-click-closing of tabs. It behaves strangely - some kind of paste operation to the URL field seems to be going on.
If middle-click-closing of tabs in Eclipse bothers Linux people, we should discuss this again.
About the Mac - yes, most Macs only have one mouse button, so I don't think this feature would hurt them. ;-)
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of bug 156792 ***

Bug.Summery: Wrong behavior in EclipseBundleData.generateManifest(Dictionary)
Bug.WithStack: org.eclipse.core.runtime.adaptor.EclipseBundleData.generateManifest(Dictionary) first creates manifest data afresh and then replaces them with cached data. In my case I was starting a runtime workbench, generateManifest first loaded data from plugin manifest, then replaced them with cached data from .metadata\.plugins\org.eclipse.pde.core\Launch\org.eclipse.osgi\manifests that somehow got corrupted. As a result the affected plugin didn't load. Cna you be more specific about what values were being overwritten. The best bet is to attach all the relevant manifest.mf and plugin.xml files. In my case it replaced the correct Provide-Package property generated by PluginConverterImpl.generateProvidePackage() from plugin.xml with a truncated version of the same property from the cached .MF (the truncated version contained only one entry, "CVS"). I haven't saved that MF, sorry. Can you still reproduce this bug on Eclipse 3.1? I have not reproduced. Closing as works for me. Please reopen if you can reproduce on Eclipse 3.1. thanks.
Bug.WithOutStack: org.eclipse.core.runtime.adaptor.EclipseBundleData.generateManifest(Dictionary) first creates manifest data afresh and then replaces them with cached data. In my case I was starting a runtime workbench, generateManifest first loaded data from plugin manifest, then replaced them with cached data from .metadata\.plugins\org.eclipse.pde.core\Launch\org.eclipse.osgi\manifests that somehow got corrupted. As a result the affected plugin didn't load. Cna you be more specific about what values were being overwritten. The best bet is to attach all the relevant manifest.mf and plugin.xml files. In my case it replaced the correct Provide-Package property generated by PluginConverterImpl.generateProvidePackage() from plugin.xml with a truncated version of the same property from the cached .MF (the truncated version contained only one entry, "CVS"). I haven't saved that MF, sorry. Can you still reproduce this bug on Eclipse 3.1? I have not reproduced. Closing as works for me. Please reopen if you can reproduce on Eclipse 3.1. thanks.

Bug.Summery: SWT Rowlayout - Margin controls not working as expected.
Bug.WithStack:
Create an empty visual class in a java project that has the SWT libraries added. Drop a Shell on to the empty canvas and size it appropriatly. And set it to Rowlayout. Then drop an number of SWT widgets on to the Shell amd then set text to the components that can take text. Bring up the Customize layout dialog, and play aound with the 'Spacing' controls, or change these in the Properties view or in the Source.
Here, it is really unclear as to what is the functionality of 'Margin Bottom', 'Margin Left', 'Margin Right' and 'Margin Top'?
'Margin Bottom' and 'Margin Right' seem to perform no functionality. While 'Margin Left', and 'Margin Top' do the same function as 'Margin Height' and 'Margin Width'. The reason it appears they don't do anything is because you had a fixed size shell. Since the size of the shell was fixed you couldn't tell that anything was happening on the right/bottom.
If instead you did a set size to default on the shell, then the shell will resize itself to preferred sizes. Then when you did a margin left, you will see that the margin on the left grows while the margin on the right stays the same. If you did margin right, then it will grow on the right while the left would stay the same. If you did margin width then both sides would grow. The same happens with bottom and height. closing
Bug.WithOutStack:
Create an empty visual class in a java project that has the SWT libraries added. Drop a Shell on to the empty canvas and size it appropriatly. And set it to Rowlayout. Then drop an number of SWT widgets on to the Shell amd then set text to the components that can take text. Bring up the Customize layout dialog, and play aound with the 'Spacing' controls, or change these in the Properties view or in the Source.
Here, it is really unclear as to what is the functionality of 'Margin Bottom', 'Margin Left', 'Margin Right' and 'Margin Top'?
'Margin Bottom' and 'Margin Right' seem to perform no functionality. While 'Margin Left', and 'Margin Top' do the same function as 'Margin Height' and 'Margin Width'. The reason it appears they don't do anything is because you had a fixed size shell. Since the size of the shell was fixed you couldn't tell that anything was happening on the right/bottom.
If instead you did a set size to default on the shell, then the shell will resize itself to preferred sizes. Then when you did a margin left, you will see that the margin on the left grows while the margin on the right stays the same. If you did margin right, then it will grow on the right while the left would stay the same. If you did margin width then both sides would grow. The same happens with bottom and height. closing

Bug.Summery: .class generation pb
Bug.WithStack:
Hello, I use Eclipse 3.0 and It seems there are some pbs with .class generation (maybe ;-) ) . On several projects , it seems that when I change a .java file, the corresponding .class file is not updated/recreated. I've tried "automatic build", "Build all", "build project"...without success :-( the .class files are not regenerated... What I 've missed? So I'm not confident anymore in my .class file :-( best regards Xavier Could you please provide a test case to reproduce? Add CC' Please reopen once steps to reproduce are available. Hello, I've found the reason of the prbs I encountered. It was due to the Sysedo Tomcat plugin. The solution was described by rudolf : " Problem with Eclipse 3/Sysdeo Tomcat Launcher ("Required library cannot denote external folder...."): Open project properties --> Java Build Path --> Libraries and remove 'TOMCAT_HOME' (it's marked with a small, yellow warning sign), because this is not a java library. Eclipse 2.12 displays the same warning but ignores the not existing library. Rudolf" I don't know if there is something to do in eclipse (maybe have the former behavior as in 2.1 ?)... best regards Xavier Reopening

Bug.Summery: (Test) Doc for adding invocations of test methods to suite behavior isn't clear
Bug.WithStack: The documentation for adding test methods invocations to suite behavior is much clearer in the doc for JUnit and Manual Test. URL Test doc should point to it or copy it in it's doc. update based on requirements group review marked so requirements process will review as this has been deferred from 3.3 As of TPTP 4.6.0, TPTP is in maintenance mode and focusing on improving quality by resolving relevant defects and increasing test coverage through test creation, automation, Build Verification Tests (BVTs), and expanded run-time execution. Bug.Summery: ConcurrentModificationException closing eclipse after commit of build.xml
Bug.WithStack:
Version: 3.0.0 Build id: 200406251208 Closing eclipse after committing a change to build.xml, that was still opened in ant editor, got the following error:
!ENTRY org.eclipse.ant.ui 4 120 Jul 02, 2004 16:16:41.949 !MESSAGE Error logged from Ant UI: !STACK 0 java.util.ConcurrentModificationException at java.util.AbstractList$Itr.checkForComodification(AbstractList.java:448) at java.util.AbstractList$Itr.next(AbstractList.java:419) at org.eclipse.ant.internal.ui.editor.model.AntElementNode.getNode(AntElementNode.java:459) at org.eclipse.ant.internal.ui.editor.outline.AntModel.handleError(AntModel.java:1071) at org.eclipse.ant.internal.ui.editor.outline.AntModel.fatalError(AntModel.java:1116) at org.eclipse.ant.internal.ui.editor.utils.ProjectHelper.parse(ProjectHelper.java:511) at org.eclipse.ant.internal.ui.editor.utils.ProjectHelper.parse(ProjectHelper.java:574) at org.eclipse.ant.internal.ui.editor.outline.AntModel.parseDocument(AntModel.java:287) at org.eclipse.ant.internal.ui.editor.outline.AntModel.reconcile(AntModel.java:215) at org.eclipse.ant.internal.ui.editor.text.XMLReconcilingStrategy.internalReconcile(XMLReconcilingStrategy.java:47) at org.eclipse.ant.internal.ui.editor.text.XMLReconcilingStrategy.initialReconcile(XMLReconcilingStrategy.java:85) at org.eclipse.jface.text.reconciler.MonoReconciler.initialProcess(MonoReconciler.java:103) at org.eclipse.ant.internal.ui.editor.text.NotifyingReconciler.initialProcess(NotifyingReconciler.java:62) at org.eclipse.jface.text.reconciler.AbstractReconciler$BackgroundThread.run(AbstractReconciler.java:170) !SESSION Jul 02, 2004 16:18:34.667 --------------------------------------------- eclipse.buildId=I200406251208 java.version=1.4.2_04 java.vendor=Sun Microsystems Inc. BootLoader constants: OS=win32, ARCH=x86, WS=win32, NL=en_US
On reopening, the build.xml was wrongly flagged in error due to a "missing default compile target", that was simply not true. The only way to remove the error flag was to close the build.xml editor, close eclipse, reopen eclipse and edit again build.xml. As soon as the editor reopened, the error flag disappeared.
The commit was completed since about five minutes when i closed eclipse, so there was no concurrence between it and the closing. It is a one time occurrence, and i have not been able to reproduce it again. Was the Ant editor you made the change in the only Ant editor that was open? No it wasn't. I had another ant editor opened with a build.xml from another project, an xml file opened with XMLBuddy and some java editors, may be 5/6, i don't remember the exact number. Just to prevent your question, XMLBuddy is still the version 2.0.8 and not the 2.0.10 that is unusable since it breaks the ant editor. Gabriele I have not seen or been able to reproduce this problem. Have you seen it at all recently? Hi Darin, it was easily reproduceable, at least for me, with 3.0.0, but i didn't saw it anymore since going to 3.0.1 and then to 3.1.0. My be it was an induced problem and that somehow it was solved on the way to 3.0.1, so if you agree, i think we can close the bug, so you can shorten your list by one :)
Thanks, Gabriele. Thank you for reporting back.
Marking worksforme.

My be it was an induced problem and that somehow it was solved on the way to 3.0.1, so if you agree, i think we can close the bug, so you can shorten your list by one :)

Bug.Summery: SWT RowLayout - UNDO not functioning as expected
Bug.WithStack:
Create a new Visual Class extenting other and the Object superclass, in a java project that the SWT library added.
Drop a SWT Shell on to the canvas, and select its layout as RowLayout.
Drop 8 or 9 separate SWT components on to the Shell. Then select two or three these and move them around on the Shell. Select 'Undo' just once (then sit back and watch the show).
Instead of just un-doing the last action, it un-does the last six or seven actions at once - plus creating errors. Sri, I think this may be a dup of bug 69478 This a has scenario that is different but the results are the same... tons of flashing, redrawing, etc. and incorrect behavior. Same symptoms and stack trace as bug 69137

Bug.Summery: The shared libraries looses its permission - Export-> Deployable feature

Lines.Line: 1)There are files by name libspawner.so and libpty.so in
org.eclipse.cdt.core.linux/os/linux/x86. I gave them all rights / permission
2)Using Export -> Deployable feature, export the plugin as xyz.zip.
3)Unzip this file.
4) Now go and check the permission of those shared file, it will not have 777
permission.

Bug.WithStack:
When we export a project as Export -> Deployable feature option, the shared libraries looses its permission level.
How to reproduce? 1)There are files by name libspawner.so and libpty.so in org.eclipse.cdt.core.linux/os/linux/x86. I gave them all rights / permission ie., 777.
2)Using Export -> Deployable feature, export the plugin as xyz.zip.
3)Unzip this file.
4) Now go and check the permission of those shared file, it will not have 777 permission.
Can somebody help me to find out a work around for this issue ? PR was not targeted to any particular release. Changing target milestone to 2.1 I don't think this has anything at all to do with the CDT, but it shouldn't gate the release. I am marking this future. Future means you commit to fix it in the Future. Inboxes can't make committments. Moving to '--'.
Bug.WithOutStack:
When we export a project as Export -> Deployable feature option, the shared libraries looses its permission level.
How to reproduce? 1)There are files by name libspawner.so and libpty.so in org.eclipse.cdt.core.linux/os/linux/x86. I gave them all rights / permission ie., 777.
2)Using Export -> Deployable feature, export the plugin as xyz.zip.
3)Unzip this file.
4) Now go and check the permission of those shared file, it will not have 777 permission.
Can somebody help me to find out a work around for this issue ? PR was not targeted to any particular release. Changing target milestone to 2.1 I don't think this has anything at all to do with the CDT, but it shouldn't gate the release. I am marking this future. Future means you commit to fix it in the Future. Inboxes can't make committments. Moving to '--'.

Bug.Summery: Always tells me the workspace is in use
Bug.WithStack:
When I start eclipse 3.0, I get an error when I try to create a workspace on my account on a network. I was using Eclipse 2.0.13 before and it was fine.
Whatever name I choose for the new workspace I get the error : "Workspace is in use, choose a different one"
Even if i enter a workspace directory that doesn't exist, I get the error. After the error message I can see that the directory that I specified was created along with its .metadata subdir and inside the .metadata dir, there was a .lock file. If I delete that lock file I still get the same error.
The eclipse installation is on /tmp/eclipse because I don't have access to other directories on the local hard disk and I don't want it to run from the network.
If I set the workspace to be on /tmp, it works without a glitch. If I choose a workspace directory on the network, I get the error described above, and this even if I chmod the workspace dir to 777. not sure why this ended up in the Intro bucket. transfering to platform. See also bug 55744 comment 7 for a workaround.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 44735 ***
Bug.WithOutStack:
When I start eclipse 3.0, I get an error when I try to create a workspace on my account on a network. I was using Eclipse 2.0.13 before and it was fine.

The eclipse installation is on /tmp/eclipse because I don't have access to other directories on the local hard disk and I don't want it to run from the network.
If I set the workspace to be on /tmp, it works without a glitch. Bug.Summery: When working with C source using C++ keywords interferes with the outliner
Bug.WithStack:
The outliner (silently) leaves off certain valid C functions because they contain C++ keywords. I guess they break the outliners parser but its still annoying.
Although I observed to problem is a complex program the following, very simple, example demonstrates the problem. The function will not be displayed in the outline view because it uses the C++ reserved word 'this' as the name of its argument.
static int breakTheOutliner(int this) { return this + 1; } Is the containing project a C or C++ project? What type of file (.h, .C, .cc etc.) contains this declaration? This problem manifested itself on a 'Standard C Make', the source file ended .c and I was using Eclipse 3.0 RC3 with CDT 2.0 M9.
The problem no longer manifests itself using the overnight builds (I tested CDT 2.0 I20040628).
Note that there were severe problems storing settings for this type of project in M9 (see bug 69147). I think it possible that this bug was, in fact, another manifestation of that problem. Using the 2.0 release, I created a new Standard C make project with a file named t.c, and the given code works fine in the outline view.
The problem would be explained by the project telling the parser the wrong language for the file, which now seems to be working.
Bug.WithOutStack:
The outliner (silently) leaves off certain valid C functions because they contain C++ keywords. I guess they break the outliners parser but its still annoying.
Although I observed to problem is a complex program the following, very simple, example demonstrates the problem. The function will not be displayed in the outline view because it uses the C++ reserved word 'this' as the name of its argument.
static int breakTheOutliner(int this) { return this + 1; } Is the containing project a C or C++ project? What type of file (.h, .C, .cc etc.) contains this declaration? This problem manifested itself on a 'Standard C Make', the source file ended .c and I was using Eclipse 3.0 RC3 with CDT 2.0 M9.
The problem no longer manifests itself using the overnight builds (I tested CDT 2.0 I20040628).
Note that there were severe problems storing settings for this type of project in M9 (see bug 69147). I think it possible that this bug was, in fact, another manifestation of that problem. Using the 2.0 release, I created a new Standard C make project with a file named t.c, and the given code works fine in the outline view.
The problem would be explained by the project telling the parser the wrong language for the file, which now seems to be working.

Bug.Summery: C editor leaves resource out of sync with the file system
Bug.WithStack:
3.0 + CDT 2.0RC2 To reproduce, I right click on the project and select Refresh just to make sure everything is in sync (this is optional). Then I edit one .c file in my project and save it. Then I do a Search > File and type in the name of some string that appears in this and other files. (Note this is the regular file search and not the C++ search since C++ search doesn't work for me.) When I hit return, I get a dialog that says "Problems encountered during text search" with the detail info of "Resource is out of sync with the file system" and listing the file I just edited. I'm positive that there is no other process besides Eclipse modifying these files. I do not have the Refresh workspace automatically option turned on.
It doesn't happen every time. For example as I was writing this it was happening ever time. Then I closed the editor and reopened it on the same .c file and it would not happen at all. There are many previous errors in the log. Here's the tail end of the log including one error about 10 minutes previous to the sync error:

Bug.Summery: [Markers] Sort in Tasks and Problems views doesn't work with filter.
Bug.WithStack:
In the Tasks view and in the Problems view, when the filter "on selected resource and its children" is enabled, sorting a column hides the tasks/problems.
How to reproduce: In the problems (or tasks) view, enable the filter "on selected resource and its children". Select in the navigator or in the package explorer a project with problems. Click on a column in the problems view: the problems list is empty.
If you click on the project again, the problems list is displayed and correctly sorted. The same problem occurs with "on any resource in same project", "on selected resource only", but it works fine with the filter "on any resource".
eclipse 2.1.3 doesn't have this problem. I assume you are using 3.0 (release version - June 25 - 12:08) Yes, I do. It's not a Milestone or integration build, it's the release version. This is working in 3.2 M2

Bug.Summery: Line numbers behave like whole file was modified
Bug.WithStack:
After some time editing/saving a Java source file with line numbering turned on, the ruler becomes "pink", as if all the lines of the file were changed. Such behavior seems to appear after version 3.0, because in RC3 it didn't occur.
System configuration is Windows 2000 SP4, with all MS patches until this date (but no patch applied since RC3). Steps to reproduce:
. Open a .java file with more lines than the screen height . Go to the last line on the screen (not on the file) . Press ENTER
This will happen when there are too many differences between the document in the editor and the reference document (e.g. cvs), so that the diff information cannot be computed using a sane amount of memory. I don't see this when changing just one single line.
This was introduced late in 3.0 to guard against high memory consumption.
Works as expected, please reopen if you see this when there is only one single difference.
Bug.WithOutStack:
After some time editing/saving a Java source file with line numbering turned on, the ruler becomes "pink", as if all the lines of the file were changed. Such behavior seems to appear after version 3.0, because in RC3 it didn't occur.
System configuration is Windows 2000 SP4, with all MS patches until this date (but no patch applied since RC3). Steps to reproduce:
. Open a .java file with more lines than the screen height . Go to the last line on the screen (not on the file) . Press ENTER
This will happen when there are too many differences between the document in the editor and the reference document (e.g. cvs), so that the diff information cannot be computed using a sane amount of memory. I don't see this when changing just one single line.
This was introduced late in 3.0 to guard against high memory consumption.
Works as expected, please reopen if you see this when there is only one single difference.

Bug.Summery: [EditorMgmt] Specification/Safety Problem with IEditorInput interface and Workbench

Lines.Line: 1) specify that getToolTipText on IEditorInput should _never_ return null.
2) OR (better), protect the call in WorkbenchLabelProvider.getText so that if
an EditorPart.getToolTipText returns null, it just returns some default value.
I think this issue has been resolved. Stefan?
IEditorInput has never been allowed to return null from getToolTipText.
LabelProvider's assumption is fine. More explicit javadoc has been added, and a
null check has been added to the part conformance test.

Bug.WithStack:
This is a little complex, sorry if the explanation seems incoherent.
WorkbenchPartLabelProvider can be made to generate a NullPointerException if someone creates a new IEditorInput and returns null from the getToolTipText function.
The NullPointerException occurs when you try to close Eclipse with dirty editor (s) whose IEditorInput return null from getToolTipText. The reason appears to be because the workbench tries to compile a list of editors to query the user "Should I save these before exit". When the workbench does this, it's LabelProvider.getText function makes the assumption (probably the real bug) that getToolTipText on every EditorPart never returns null. This can result because the default implementation of EditorPart uses IEditorInput.getToolTipText.
My suggestion is either:
1) specify that getToolTipText on IEditorInput should _never_ return null. 2) OR (better), protect the call in WorkbenchLabelProvider.getText so that if an EditorPart.getToolTipText returns null, it just returns some default value. I think this issue has been resolved. Stefan? IEditorInput has never been allowed to return null from getToolTipText. LabelProvider's assumption is fine. More explicit javadoc has been added, and a null check has been added to the part conformance test.
If the workbench detects that an editor input is returning null from getToolTipText, it will now refuse to create that editor and substitute an error part instead. Fixed Verified in I20050510-0010
Bug.WithOutStack:
This is a little complex, sorry if the explanation seems incoherent.
WorkbenchPartLabelProvider can be made to generate a NullPointerException if someone creates a new IEditorInput and returns null from the getToolTipText function.
The NullPointerException occurs when you try to close Eclipse with dirty editor (s) whose IEditorInput return null from getToolTipText. The reason appears to be because the workbench tries to compile a list of editors to query the user "Should I save these before exit". When the workbench does this, it's LabelProvider.getText function makes the assumption (probably the real bug) that getToolTipText on every EditorPart never returns null. This can result because the default implementation of EditorPart uses IEditorInput.getToolTipText.
My suggestion is either:
1) specify that getToolTipText on IEditorInput should _never_ return null. 2) OR (better), protect the call in WorkbenchLabelProvider.getText so that if an EditorPart.getToolTipText returns null, it just returns some default value. I think this issue has been resolved. Stefan? IEditorInput has never been allowed to return null from getToolTipText. LabelProvider's assumption is fine. More explicit javadoc has been added, and a null check has been added to the part conformance test.
If the workbench detects that an editor input is returning null from getToolTipText, it will now refuse to create that editor and substitute an error part instead. Fixed Verified in I20050510-0010

Bug.Summery: Eclipse 2.1.2 plugin does not load in eclipse RC3
Bug.WithStack:
Hi, We have already deployed plugin written against the eclipse version 2.x. Our plugin has a dependency on the xerces plugin which was part of the installed plugins in eclipse 2.x and upto 3.0M8. In eclipse RC3 the xerces plugin has being removed from the plugins installed with eclipse. So when we try to install and load our pluign into 3.0RC3 it does not load. I ran eclipse with the -console option and in the OSGI console i found out that the reason for the failure was indeed the missing xerces plugin from 3.0RC3.
I know that in 3.0 we are supposed to use the xerces passer from the jdk, but this does not solve the situation where you already have deployed 2.x plugins with the xerces plugin in there dependency list. Please let me know what needs to be done to make my 2.x plugin work in 3.0rc3.
Thanks in Advance Anthony Candappa You can either patch the existing plug-ins by removing the dependency on Xerces (I believe you don't have any explicit dependency on Xerces other than the plug-in prerequisite), or provide an empty Xerces plug-in (just a placeholder) to your users. Hi Rafael, We have an explicit dependency on the xerces plugin. We have imports for import org.apache.xerces.dom.DocumentImpl; import org.apache.xerces.parsers.DOMParser;
and if we put the stub for the xerces plugin like you are suggesting, the plugin loads fine, but when we initiate any operation that uses the xerces plugin we get a NoClassDefFound exception.
I know we can patch our install and compile it to be 3.0 compatible, but we have several clients with the old 2.x binaries that might want to move to eclipse 3.0 before we ship another version/patch, and the current 2.x binary of our plugin will not work out of the box with eclipse 3.0.
Any other suggestions?
Thanks in Advance, Anthony Candappa Please see bug 37696 and the following message from the mailing list for info/suggestions: http://dev.eclipse.org/mhonarc/lists/eclipse-dev/msg04227.html
The equivalent functionality from xerces is available in the 1.4 JDK. Please consult the Eclipse 3.0 porting guide for details (Help > Help Contents > Platform Plugin Developers Guide > Programmer's Guide > 3.0 Plug-in Migration Guide > Incompatibilities > 4. Removal of Xerces plugin.
Bug.WithOutStack:
Hi, We have already deployed plugin written against the eclipse version 2.x. Our plugin has a dependency on the xerces plugin which was part of the installed plugins in eclipse 2.x and upto 3.0M8. In eclipse RC3 the xerces plugin has being removed from the plugins installed with eclipse. So when we try to install and load our pluign into 3.0RC3 it does not load. I ran eclipse with the -console option and in the OSGI console i found out that the reason for the failure was indeed the missing xerces plugin from 3.0RC3.
I know that in 3.0 we are supposed to use the xerces passer from the jdk, but this does not solve the situation where you already have deployed 2.x plugins with the xerces plugin in there dependency list. Please let me know what needs to be done to make my 2.x plugin work in 3.0rc3.
Thanks in Advance Anthony Candappa You can either patch the existing plug-ins by removing the dependency on Xerces (I believe you don't have any explicit dependency on Xerces other than the plug-in prerequisite), or provide an empty Xerces plug-in (just a placeholder) to your users. Hi Rafael, We have an explicit dependency on the xerces plugin. We have imports for import org.apache.xerces.dom.DocumentImpl; import org.apache.xerces.parsers.DOMParser;
and if we put the stub for the xerces plugin like you are suggesting, the plugin loads fine, but when we initiate any operation that uses the xerces plugin we get a NoClassDefFound exception.
I know we can patch our install and compile it to be 3.0 compatible, but we have several clients with the old 2.x binaries that might want to move to eclipse 3.0 before we ship another version/patch, and the current 2.x binary of our plugin will not work out of the box with eclipse 3.0.
Any other suggestions?
Thanks in Advance, Anthony Candappa Please see bug 37696 and the following message from the mailing list for info/suggestions: http://dev.eclipse.org/mhonarc/lists/eclipse-dev/msg04227.html
The equivalent functionality from xerces is available in the 1.4 JDK. Please consult the Eclipse 3.0 porting guide for details (Help > Help Contents > Platform Plugin Developers Guide > Programmer's Guide > 3.0 Plug-in Migration Guide > Incompatibilities > 4. Removal of Xerces plugin.

Bug.Summery: Debugger says 'source code not found', but it is present
Bug.WithStack:
Hello, I sometimes (often?) get this error message:
C/C++ File Editor
Source not found Can not find the file 'C:\full\path\to\source.cpp' in the specified source locations. You can attach a new source location by pressing the button below.
[Attach Source...]
However, the file 'C:\full\path\to\source.cpp' actually does exist. If I click 'Attach Source', and cut and paste the path, ''C:\full\path\to\' into the 'add directory' entry, the editor is able to load the file.
It seems to me the editor can't detect that the file name is an absolute path and load it, rather it assumes the full path is simply relative.
This is with Eclipse 3.0 and CDT RC2. This is an expected behavior. The debugger only looks for files in the source locations specified in the launch configuration. Even if the absolute path is provided the source location should be added to the list. This seems counter-intutitive for non-managed projects. IE, for projects that have Makefiles not handled by Eclipse, why should the user have to duplicate all sorts of source path entries in the eclipse configuration when its already provided to the debugger explicitly?
If a full path is provided, why can't the Eclipse automatically add the path to launch configuration? It seems strange for Eclipse to say "I can't find this file, which is staring me right in the face".
As a last comment, if this is by design and expected behavior, how about enhancing the error message to explain that? Could the error message say "File located, but path must be in launch configuration"? I agree, it is not intuitive. The source location list is also used to filter breakpoints that do not belong to the project. Anyway, the implementation of the source lookup will be changed to adjust it to the new approach used by the Eclipse platform. And this comment will be taken in account. For the next release I will modify the message. Oh, perhaps that explains why some of my breakpoints were not being fired. Anyway, thank you for taking this into consideration. Fixed.

Bug.Summery: container will not shrink in the Dependencies, Runtime and Build tabs of the manifest editor
Bug.WithStack:
Using Linux GTK
Steps:
* Open any plugin.xml with the manifest editor * Select the Dependencies tab * Use the bottom right of the eclipse window to make the eclipse window bigger. Notice that the "Required Plug-ins" container grows as the eclipse window gets bigger. * Use the bottom right of the eclipse window to make the eclipse window smaller. Notice that the "Required Plug-ins" conatiner does not get smaller as the eclipse window gets smaller.
Other Notes:
* The Runtime and Build tabs have the same problem. * The other tabs (ie. Overview) do not have this problem.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 65400 ***
Bug.WithOutStack:
Using Linux GTK
Steps:
* Open any plugin.xml with the manifest editor * Select the Dependencies tab * Use the bottom right of the eclipse window to make the eclipse window bigger. Notice that the "Required Plug-ins" container grows as the eclipse window gets bigger. * Use the bottom right of the eclipse window to make the eclipse window smaller. Notice that the "Required Plug-ins" conatiner does not get smaller as the eclipse window gets smaller.
Other Notes:
* The Runtime and Build tabs have the same problem. * The other tabs (ie. Overview) do not have this problem.

Bug.Summery: Importing Preferences overwrites existing classpath variable values
Bug.WithStack:
If you Export your Eclipse Preferences on one workstation and then Import them on another, any pre-existing classpath variable values on the second workstation will be overwritten with the newly-imported values. This includes Reserved variables such as JRE_LIB, which cannot be subsequently corrected by the user (hence the Major severity of this bug).
I think the way this should work is that variables which already exist on the importing workstation should not be overwritten. Variables which don't already exist may be created, which will give the user a cue that s/he can subsequently alter them (their values will probably be different between workstations). At the very least, the Import should ask what to do, but NEVER overwrite Reserved variables. If you still have a backup of a V2 Eclipse workspace, you can work around the loss of variables values by copying the old ...\workspace\.metadata\.plugins\org.eclipse.jdt.core\pref_store.ini file to the corresponding V3 workspace directory and restarting Eclipse. Plug-in preference values are cleared at the destination when importing. This is designed behaviour. Part of the motivation is that a user who exports preferences from one machine and then imports them on another machine will have exactly the same preferences on the same machine.
Moving to JDT/Core for comment w.r.t. the handling of reserved classpath variables like JRE_LIB. Yes, but there are important differences between IDE preferences and Project environment setups. In this case, it's highly likely that paths will be different between workstations, so the variables should not be blindly cleared and/or overwritten. -This is why the user has factored out the class paths to environment variables in the first place. Changing the variable values will almost certainly break the project. As it is now, the net effect of the current behavior is that IDE settings cannot be exchanged between co-workers, or even the same person between workstations. Another way to work around this problem (if you know ahead of time), is to remove the variable definition lines from the exported preferences file before importing it on the second workstation. JRE_LIB is reserved by JDT UI. Moving to JDT UI for comment. Some additional comments:
- the new export story we define for 3.0 will allow controlling which settings get exported and which don't. So it will be the responibility of the export to handle this, not the import. As DJ pointed out importing always means importing everything.
The value of the JRE_LIB variable can be controlled via the preference page "Installed JREs". By selecting a different JRE and reselecting the one you want should be a better workaround.
Moving to Debug since they own the variable.
In M5, it is possible to specify groups of prefs when exporting/importing preferences. However, looking at the support in org.eclispe.ui.preferenceTransfer (extension), you can only specify groups of prefs to selectively export/import, or export/import all. This does not quite allow us to fix this problem - i.e. the user want to say export everything except these things (like JRE_LIB, installed JREs, etc). The UI does not allow this in its current state.
It's not clear if the preferences should never be exported/imported, of if the user should have a chance to export/import them. When exporting the prefs to use on a different workstation, it does not make sense to keep them (as installation locations will likely be different). However, there are cases where it makes sense to keep them (when setting up a new workspace on the same machine).
It feels like validating a preference on import and rejecting it if invalid could be useful. Yes, regarding your last comment, I believe that using preferenceTransfer in combination with the preference apply intercepter should give you what you need (see bug 88322). This support from core will allow one to make changes to their preferences before they get applied (most cases through import but not always). In your case you can wipe out the jre if you feel that should be done.
On export if "Export all" where chosen you have no option to stop this, but you could re-org preferences slightly or design a preferenceTransfer to export various preference and not include the node that has the jre if that were appropriate. Fixed. Added an org.eclipse.core.runtime.preferences extension to jdt.launching. Our modify listener merges JREs being imported into the existing JRE settings. Invalid JREs are discarded.
Changes to
plugin.xml JREPreferenceModifyListener Please verify, Kevin. verified

Bug.Summery: Incorrect 'diff' shown when merging code
Bug.WithStack:
Occasionally, when I merge code from and earlier release of my Java project (we use multiple branches in CVS), the comparison window shows conflicts (in red) for large parts of the file (often the entire file). This happens even if there is a single line change between the file.
When I use a 3rd party tool (ex: WinMerge) it correctly shows the minimal difference.
The problem is not predictable but is reproducible once it happens (that is, I get the same results each time I attempt to merge the same file using an earlier release).
In some instances when I visually pick out the actual differences and manually make the changes and save the updated file, the red-marked diffs go away.
This problem has been observed since release 2 of eclipse and is still there in release 3. This can occur if the (invisible) line-separators differ. Often this is a result of sharing files between Windows and Unix and don't have the files checked into CVS correctly marked as "text". You can fix the line delimiters in the Eclipse editor with "Convert Line Delimiters to.." and you can fix the incorrect CVS attribute via "Team > Change ASCII/Binary property".
In addition, you can turn the "Ignore Whitespace" option on for Compare.
Let me know if this fixes the problem. An additional observation:
When a chunk of code shows up as red (conflicting changes), I can sometimes visually locate the one line or two out of the entire range of lines marked in red. I can then copy and paste them into the merged-into file and save it. The red markings then go away.
Somehow, rather than just show the few lines that have changed (from an earlier branch), an entire range of lines (often the entire file) shows up as conflicting changes. We can't really do anything to fix this unless we can reprodice the problem. Could you attach the 2 or three file copies involved so we can try and reproduce this? Our usual practice is to move bugs to the RESOLVED REMIND state when there is not enough information provided to address the reported issue and more information has been requested. This bug has been in the RESOLVED REMIND state for quite some time so it is being CLOSED. If you can provide the requested information or you otherwise feel that this is still an issue, please reopen the bug. If you are unable to open it due to a lack or permissions, please add a comment to the bug stating that you would like to have the request reconsidered. I applogize for this blanket approach to bug screening but there are just to many bugs in the REMIND state for us to effectively triage them. Your help in this matter is appreciated. [REMIND->INVALID] The "REMIND" bugzilla resolution is being removed so reopening to mark as INVALID. INVALID. Closing.

Bug.Summery: 2 threads inside a synchronized block
Bug.WithStack:
In the attached image you will see that I am debugging a simple thread program. By selecting individual threads I can enter the synchronized block event though the other thread is already in the synchronized block. In the attached image you can see the line numbers of the statck traces indicate both are inside the synchronized block...I am not sure if I am doing anything wrong here.
Using eclipse 3.0 Created attachment 12948 Debug snapshot showing 2 threads in a synchronized block of code. This is how Java works. If a non-static method is marked as synchronized, the lock use to do the synchronization in the current instance ('this'). You created two different objects, two different locks are used, the two thread can in the method at the same time. Depends on what you want to do, the solution is : create only one object, set the method static, or create your own lock (static) and use it in a synchronize statement.
See http://java.sun.com/docs/books/jls/second_edition/html/classes.doc.html#260369
Btw, Eclipse doesn't do anything in this case, it just displays the information sent by the VM. thanx for clearing it up....I goofed up:-)
Bug.WithOutStack:
In the attached image you will see that I am debugging a simple thread program. By selecting individual threads I can enter the synchronized block event though the other thread is already in the synchronized block. In the attached image you can see the line numbers of the statck traces indicate both are inside the synchronized block...I am not sure if I am doing anything wrong here.
Using eclipse 3.0 Created attachment 12948 Debug snapshot showing 2 threads in a synchronized block of code. This is how Java works. If a non-static method is marked as synchronized, the lock use to do the synchronization in the current instance ('this'). You created two different objects, two different locks are used, the two thread can in the method at the same time. Depends on what you want to do, the solution is : create only one object, set the method static, or create your own lock (static) and use it in a synchronize statement.
See http://java.sun.com/docs/books/jls/second_edition/html/classes.doc.html#260369
Btw, Eclipse doesn't do anything in this case, it just displays the information sent by the VM. thanx for clearing it up....I goofed up:-)

Bug.Summery: Fully qualify the Ant partition name

source_code.code: /** * The name of the Ant partitioning. * @since 3.0 */
/** * The name of the Ant partitioning. * @since 3.0 */

Bug.WithStack:
Instead of just using in AntDocumentSetupParticipant: /** * The name of the Ant partitioning. * @since 3.0 */ public final static String ANT_PARTITIONING= "___ant_partitioning";
we should use something like: /** * The name of the Ant partitioning. * @since 3.0 */ public final static String ANT_PARTITIONING= "org.eclipse.ant.ui.antPartitioning"; Changed in AntDocumentSetupParticipant. Please verify DarinW. Verified.

Bug.Summery: DEBUG logging in DCE causes crash when printing env vars containing % chars
Bug.WithStack:
Turning DEBUG logging on in the RAC sometimes causes RAC crashes. It happens when printing out the environment variables in modifyApplicationEnvironment in launcher.c. It is caused by environment variable values that contain % signs.
ra_logServiceMessage in RAServerConfigBinding.cpp uses fprintf(_logFile, _preBuffer) to print out the log message to the file. But if the log message in _preBuffer contains % followed by a valid type specifier character (eg. %l or %n), that two character substring will not appear in the log message and sometimes causes fprintf to blow up. I have only noticed this on windows machines when trying to debug customer problems.
I suggest to replace fprintf with fwrite. For example:
fwrite(_preBuffer, 1, strlen(_preBuffer), _logFile) For example, a customer had the following environment variable: NLSPATH=C:\ifor\LS\MSG\N;C:\IBM Connectors\Encina\%l\%n;C:\IBMVJava\eab\msg\%n;
But here is what was printed out in the servicelog.log:
<SERVER_MSG time="2003:9:4:8:11:23" severity="DEBUG" text="Changed Env Entry: NLSPATH=C:\ifor\LS\MSG\N;C:\IBM Connectors\Encina\\
and then the DCE crashed. Committed suggested change to Head. As of TPTP 4.6.0, TPTP is in maintenance mode and focusing on improving quality by resolving relevant enhancements/defects and increasing test coverage through test creation, automation, Build Verification Tests (BVTs), and expanded run-time execution. As part of the TPTP Bugzilla housecleaning process (see http://wiki.eclipse.org/Bugzilla_Housecleaning_Processes), this enhancement/defect is verified/closed by the Project Lead since this originator of this enhancement/defect has an inactive Bugzilla account and considered to be fixed. If this enhancement/defect is still unresolved and reproducible in the latest TPTP release (http://www.eclipse.org/tptp/home/downloads/), please re-open.

and then the DCE crashed. Committed suggested change to Head. As part of the TPTP Bugzilla housecleaning process (see http://wiki.eclipse.org/Bugzilla_Housecleaning_Processes), this enhancement/defect is verified/closed by the Project Lead since this originator of this enhancement/defect has an inactive Bugzilla account and considered to be fixed. If this enhancement/defect is still unresolved and reproducible in the latest TPTP release (http://www.eclipse.org/tptp/home/downloads/), please re-open.

Bug.Summery: [Workbench] Toolbars, Tabs too fat on GTK Linux

Lines.Line: 1. GtkWidget border (usually set to 0 by the theme)
2. A hard-coded 1 pixel spacer (not overridable)
3. GtkWidget "thickness", used for the button shadow (usually 2 pixels)
4. Space for the dotted focus line (1 pixel) and some padding (usually 1 pixel)
1. The button shadow is 1 pixel instead of 2 pixels
2. Toolbar buttons appear raised instead of having a dotted focus border
3. There is a 2-pixel padding around each icon before the button shadow

Bug.WithStack:
Toolbars and tabs are too fat on GTK Linux compared to Windows, leaving too few space for the editor. Toolbars has unused space above and below buttons, while tabs has lot of unused space above and below text. I tried different themes, but it makes no difference. This is a common observation that bugged me so I did some research.
Toolbar buttons in GTK+ are normal GTK+ buttons. The border around their contents consists of the following:
1. GtkWidget border (usually set to 0 by the theme) 2. A hard-coded 1 pixel spacer (not overridable) 3. GtkWidget "thickness", used for the button shadow (usually 2 pixels) 4. Space for the dotted focus line (1 pixel) and some padding (usually 1 pixel)
This usually creates a 5 pixel border at every edge of the button. Comparing with Eclipse on Windows XP I see:
1. The button shadow is 1 pixel instead of 2 pixels 2. Toolbar buttons appear raised instead of having a dotted focus border 3. There is a 2-pixel padding around each icon before the button shadow
This gives a total of 3 pixels of border, except for the top and right hand sides which have an extra padding pixel for a total of 4 pixels.
So the difference is usually 3 pixels in height. The shadows could be made thinner by the theme, and the focus padding can also be removed. It seems that most GTK+ themes like big buttons, but through google I found a theme called "Smooth-Professional" that removes the focus padding. Billy what do you want to do with this bug then? Close as WONTFIX, we should not override GTK+'s behaviour on this. Closing, thank you for taking the time to log this however. Please confirm that you agree with comment #1 as well. OK, I will submit big toolbars bug to Gtk theme, but what about tabs? >it< is the main problem. In CDT I have opened editor windows (have tabs) and console/problems (also have tabs). It means that inapropriate size of tabs (in height) is multiplyed by 2. In Windows, tabs are cca 3/5 size of Gtk's. The tabs are made to be tall enough that the toolbar can fit up on the tab area. Does this match what you are seeing? Yes, It fits tab area in both cases. Does it mean tab area in gtk is too big, and you cannot make it smaller in eclipse itself? Same case as toolbar? One more note, I looked to Gtk "Notepad" widget at: http://www.gtk.org/tutorial/sec-notebooks.html
and it looks ok (not over-sized in height at all). I just mean that Eclipse sets the size of the tabs to be "big enough to fit a toolbar", since otherwise you would have some tabs taller than others depending on whether or not they have a toolbar in the tab area and it would not be visually consistent. If you look at the tabs in gedit which include a close button (also a GtkButton) in their tab, they are the same size as the tabs in Eclipse. I finally get it. I can see that package explorer tab, for example, has additional toolbar. I suggest improving Preferencies -> Appearance -> Editor Tab Positions, by adding "None" option to existing "Top" and "Bottom". Are you saying you don't want there to be Editor/View tabs at all? You can also try adding these lines in your gtkrc file or the gtkrc file for your theme:
GtkWidget::focus-line-width = 0 GtkWidget::focus-padding = 0
This works for me to get thin tabs. OK, this gtkrc tweak works, and it now looks on my Gnome Desktop same/better then Windows. One of problems was also I was running it from KDE. I don't know why, but under gnome it looks so much better (Gtk application should look exactly the same). Anyway, for both Windows/Linux it would be usefull to be able to disable editor tabs: it is almost useless. You can open files on the left navigator view, you can see current file opened in main application window title. KDevelop also has tabs optional, MSVS 6 has no tabs at all, i think. In low res like 1024x768 it really makes difference. I would even disable it by default. Please consider this enhancement and, eventually rename this bug (and mark it as enhancement, not bug). OK, as this bug is resolved, I submitted new improvement about removing editor-tabs
Bug.WithOutStack:
Toolbars and tabs are too fat on GTK Linux compared to Windows, leaving too few space for the editor. Bug.Summery: Eclipse could not start when workspace is on network drive
Bug.WithStack:
When the workspace is located on a network drive on Novell Netware 6 server, Eclipse generates the following error:
Workspace Cannot be locked Could not launch the project because the associated workspace is currently in use.
The network drive isnt read only.
I tried using the sollution to a similar problem in 3.0 M7 -vmargs -Dorg.eclipse.core.runtime.ignoreLockFile but it dodnt work.
I'm using Windows 2000 AS and Windows XP Pro with JDK 1.4.2 -b28 Yes, it is the same problem (Java file locking does not work on some file systems). The workaround has changed after M7. See bug 55744 comment 7.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 44735 *** Unfortunately that solution doesnt work either. Throws same error.
Bug.WithOutStack:
When the workspace is located on a network drive on Novell Netware 6 server, Eclipse generates the following error:

The network drive isnt read only.

Bug.Summery: [browser] No more handles (java.lang.UnsatisfiedLinkError:
Bug.WithStack:
My wiki plugin (www.teaminabox.co.uk/downloads/wiki) uses the SWT browser. I have had a bug report with the information given below, which is an SWT browser error.
=== your Wiki Plugin (Version 2.0.5 and 2.0.4) crashes eclipse 3.0 (released) on a redhat 9 machine. The following messages are written to stdout:
Unhandled event loop exception Reason: No more handles (java.lang.UnsatisfiedLinkError: /scr/magellan/eclipse/plugins/org.eclipse.swt.gtk_3.0.0/os/linux/x86/libswt-mozilla-gtk-3062.so: /scr/magellan/eclipse/plugins/org.eclipse.swt.gtk_3.0.0/os/linux/x86/libswt-mozilla-gtk-3062.so: undefined symbol: _ZN4nsID5ParseEPKc) *** SWT nested exception Reason: /scr/magellan/eclipse/plugins/org.eclipse.swt.gtk_3.0.0/os/linux/x86/libswt-mozilla-gtk-3062.so: /scr/magellan/eclipse/plugins/org.eclipse.swt.gtk_3.0.0/os/linux/x86/libswt-mozilla-gtk-3062.so: undefined symbol: _ZN4nsID5ParseEPKc
This problem occurs when eclipse tries to open a file with the .wiki extension. Christophe will look at this when he gets back from vacation but in the mean time, make sure you have mozilla correctly installed. See the following FAQ entries:
http://dev.eclipse.org/viewcvs/index.cgi/%7Echeckout%7E/platform-swt- home/faq.html#browserlinux
http://dev.eclipse.org/viewcvs/index.cgi/%7Echeckout%7E/platform-swt- home/faq.html#browserlinuxrcp See bug 69609 too, this happens on Fedora Core 2 (with Mozilla or firfox providing libxpcom). Also reported to break on Debian. Why does the platform say Macintosh? Shouldn't it be PC? > Why does the platform say Macintosh? Shouldn't it be PC?
Yes, sorry about that I submitted the bug from a Mac.
Channing Can the reporter try the fixes in bug 69609 ? Yes, I'll ask him to try.
Channing The original reporter has said that the fix in bug 69609 has worked for him
Channing The Browser widget for 3.0 on Linux requires Mozilla 1.4 GTK2 build. 1.5 and 1.6 GTK2 builds should also work. 1.7 and firefox don't work. The SWT FAQ documents the requirements at: http://dev.eclipse.org/viewcvs/index.cgi/%7Echeckout%7E/platform-swt- home/faq.html#browserlinux

Bug.Summery: [reconciling] Editor shows "stale" compilation error

Lines.Line: - have more than one editor open (say A.java and B.java which refer to each other)
- change A so that B has an error (don't save)
- switch to B ==> error is shown
- switch back to A
- fix error (don't save)
- give focus to another application
- give focus back to Eclipse
- switch to B ==> error still shown

Bug.WithStack:
Eclipse has always has a small problem in that occaisionally it would show an error in the editor window (red-squiggly, with a marker) even though the error had been fixed and no longer appeared in the Tasks/Problem view. I usually just type "Space-Backspace" and save the file and it goes away.
In 3.0, this is MUCH more frequent. I'm not 100% sure of the cause, but every time I've seen in it recently, file A will have a problem, and then I'll change file B to fix it. I'll pay more attention, and see if I can obtain any more details. I assume you run plain Eclipse SDK without additional plug-ins and open a *.java file with the Java editor, right?
Is the file big? If so, it can take a while until reconcile thread has done it's work.
If you see this problem again please check whether there's anything in .log.
Yes to all your assumptions. The files are not particuarly big (a few hundred lines at most). I don't think it's a timing issue, but I'll be glad to double-check the "progress view" if thw will help to verify.
I'll check the .log.
I saw the problem again today, but there was nothing in the log. I'm not sure (unfortunately) exactly what I did/or the class relationships.
Did you refresh that file from local file system? Is the file open in multiple workbench windows? *** Bug 69449 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** I found a bug in that area and fixed it: - have more than one editor open (say A.java and B.java which refer to each other) - change A so that B has an error (don't save) - switch to B ==> error is shown - switch back to A - fix error (don't save) - give focus to another application - give focus back to Eclipse - switch to B ==> error still shown

Bug.Summery: pre tag inserts extra characters on formatting source
Bug.WithStack:
Given the following java source: /** * 
 * text:
 *
*/ public class A { } When you format the source code (by pressing ctrl+shift+F) then extra lines will be inserted as many times you format the code because the line inside the pre tag contains colon. (THe formatting problem stands if the colon is in the text and not at the end of the line.) /** * 
 * te:xt
 *
*/ public class A { } Bugs in the Java editor belong to JDT/Text. *** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 52921 ***
Bug.WithOutStack:
Given the following java source: /** * 
 * text:
 *
*/ public class A { } When you format the source code (by pressing ctrl+shift+F) then extra lines will be inserted as many times you format the code because the line inside the pre tag contains colon. (THe formatting problem stands if the colon is in the text and not at the end of the line.) /** * 
 * te:xt
 *
*/ public class A { } Bugs in the Java editor belong to JDT/Text. *** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 52921 ***

Bug.Summery: Can't launch eclipse
Bug.WithStack:
Double clicking the eclipse icon gives a dialog saying jvm terminated. Launching from command line gives a dialog to choose a workspace location. However the dialog can not be selected (can't dismiss dialog) Using build 3.0RC3 Sat, 19 Jun 2004 -- 20:00 (-0400) What version of OS and Java VM are you using? Have you tried the final version of Eclipse 3.0?
You can find instructions for how to launch Eclipse on MacOS X from the command line in "readme/readme_eclipse.html".
Using Version 10.3.4, java version "1.4.2_01" The final version of eclipse 3.0 behaves the same way. However all versions work fine on my desktop iMac and my desktop g4 with which has the same os and java version. They all fail on my G4 laptop. Since I'm running Eclipse on my G4 laptop without problems, I suspect that there is something wrong with your laptop.
Is there any (Eclipse related) output in the MacOS X Console when you double click Eclipse?
What exact version of the JVM are you using (execeute a "java -version" in a shell to get the version information). On my PowerBook I get:
java version "1.4.2_04" Java(TM) 2 Runtime Environment, Standard Edition (build 1.4.2_04-135) Java HotSpot(TM) Client VM (build 1.4.2-36, mixed mode)
My laptop had the following java version for which eclipse failed: java version "1.4.2_01" Java(TM) 2 Runtime Environment, Standard Edition (build 1.4.2_01-107) Java HotSpot(TM) Client VM (build 1.4.2-001-31, mixed mode)
I copied the java that is on my imac to my laptop and now eclipse works fine. java version "1.4.2_03" Java(TM) 2 Runtime Environment, Standard Edition (build 1.4.2_03-117.1) Java HotSpot(TM) Client VM (build 1.4.2-34, mixed mode)
I don't think that there was a general problem with Eclipse and the version of the Java VM you were using (build 1.4.2_01-107). It was probably a broken installation that got corrected by installing a more recent version on top of it. Please reopen this bug if problem reoccurs.

Bug.Summery: [formatting] Option to exclude CVS keywords inside Javadoc from formatting
Bug.WithStack:
In some cases the substituted keywords, notably the $Id$-keyword, will exceed the maximum line width. In this cases the formatter will add a line break which inhibits CVS from recognizing the keyword. That means every CVS keyword (in the edited files) has to be checked manually prior to commiting.
Please add an option to exclude CVS keywords from formatting.
An even better option would be the ability to exclude lines that match a given pattern. Those keywords are in the header, right. You can set the formatter not to format headers. Please reopen if this does not work for you.
Also note that if your header comment starts with /*- * it will not get formatted by Eclipse and most likely not by any other tool since this sort of a Java convention.
See also bug 68593. Those keywords are in the type's Javadoc comment, more precisely after the @version tag. AFAIK there is no way to exclude a single Javadoc comment from being formatted except to disable the comment formatting totally which effects all other comments as well.
So I would like to see a possibility to tell the code formatter not to touch certain lines (or more general parts of the code) that mach a configurable list of patterns. I guess that would be really helpfull, for both code and comments.
I'll reopen this bug and set the severity to enhancement.
Couldn't you put it into the header? What do you do if you have >1 type in a file? Each type has it's own file. Except for some (anonymous) inner classes. For these it is fine to get the same version id as the enclosing type.
*** Bug 101780 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** Ownership changed. *** Bug 122142 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** *** Bug 98496 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** Ownership has changed for the formatter, but I surely will not have enough time to fix your bug during the 3.5 development process, hence set its priority to P5. Please provide a patch if you definitely need the bug to be fixed in this version and I'll have a look at it... TIA

Bug.Summery: Previous plug-in version not used when newer version is deleted
Bug.WithStack:
Create a a feature that contains 1 plug-in. Let's call this feature x and plug- in y. Install this feature into Eclipse by creating a link file in the eclipse\links directory. Start eclipse and verify that the plug-in is resolved usig the OSGI console. Create an Install/Update web site that contains a new version of feature y (1.0.1) and plug-in x (1.0.1). Update feature y's feature.xml to point to this Install/Update site and configure the workbench Install/Update preferences to check for updates at startup. The next time you start eclipse you'll be prompted to install updates for feature y. Install these updates and restart the workbench. Verify that the new version of the plug-in was downloaded and resolved using the OSGI console (plug-in x should be at version 1.0.1 now). Exit eclipse. Now delete feature y 1.0.1 and plug-in x 1.0.1 using command prompt, file manager etc. Start eclipse, use the OSGI console to get a listing of bundles, notice that plug-in x is completely gone even though 1.0.0 versions of the feature and plug-in are still installed. The previous versions should be loaded and resolved. The only way I could get this plug-in back was by deleting the eclipse\configuration\org.eclipse.update\platform.xml file I think this scenario is not supported if you are not running with -clean. The reason is that all the necessary support is provided to the user to uninstall features by the UI. If we were to do the reconciliation on every start the startup would be slower.
CC'ing Dorian to see if he had anything else to say. Moving to update. The previous version of the plugin was uninstalled from the runtime. The new version is gone so it also gets uninstalled. Someone has to reinstall the old version. That would be update.configurator. This is not a supported scenario. Manually removing a feature does not in any way imply that update configurator should pick up an older version. Wehn you manually remove features, you can break other feature's dependencies, etc. If you want to revert to a previous feature version, you can open Help > Software Updates > Manage Configuration, then select the current feature (1.0.1) and select Replace by another version. Also, you can revert the entire configuration, not just that particular feature, if that's what you're looking for.
Bug.WithOutStack:
Create a a feature that contains 1 plug-in. Let's call this feature x and plug- in y. Install this feature into Eclipse by creating a link file in the eclipse\links directory. Start eclipse and verify that the plug-in is resolved usig the OSGI console. Create an Install/Update web site that contains a new version of feature y (1.0.1) and plug-in x (1.0.1). Update feature y's feature.xml to point to this Install/Update site and configure the workbench Install/Update preferences to check for updates at startup. The next time you start eclipse you'll be prompted to install updates for feature y. Install these updates and restart the workbench. Verify that the new version of the plug-in was downloaded and resolved using the OSGI console (plug-in x should be at version 1.0.1 now). Exit eclipse. Now delete feature y 1.0.1 and plug-in x 1.0.1 using command prompt, file manager etc. Start eclipse, use the OSGI console to get a listing of bundles, notice that plug-in x is completely gone even though 1.0.0 versions of the feature and plug-in are still installed. The previous versions should be loaded and resolved. The only way I could get this plug-in back was by deleting the eclipse\configuration\org.eclipse.update\platform.xml file I think this scenario is not supported if you are not running with -clean. The reason is that all the necessary support is provided to the user to uninstall features by the UI. If we were to do the reconciliation on every start the startup would be slower.
CC'ing Dorian to see if he had anything else to say. Moving to update. The previous version of the plugin was uninstalled from the runtime. The new version is gone so it also gets uninstalled. Someone has to reinstall the old version. That would be update.configurator. This is not a supported scenario. Manually removing a feature does not in any way imply that update configurator should pick up an older version. Wehn you manually remove features, you can break other feature's dependencies, etc. If you want to revert to a previous feature version, you can open Help > Software Updates > Manage Configuration, then select the current feature (1.0.1) and select Replace by another version. Also, you can revert the entire configuration, not just that particular feature, if that's what you're looking for.

Bug.Summery: [Workbench] Eclipse 3.0 Motif crashes on linux
Bug.WithStack:
Eclipse 3.0 w/ Motif GUI seems very unstable. It crashes very quickly. For example, the sequence Window-->Show view-->Navigator and then right click on a project-->Close Project crashes the software every time. The resulting dialog box says: "JVM terminated. Exit code=6." and then lists the arguments that were used in starting the vm.
I have tried this with j2sdk1.4.2_04 and _05 with the same results.
I am using SuSE Linux 8.0. I will gladly provide more information if needed. Move to Platform/UI Which version of 3.0 are you using? Is there anything in the .log file? What non-Eclipse plugins do you have installed? Which window manager are you using? Are you using the SUSE 8.0 out-of-the- box, or have you upgraded certain packages?
I would expect that you are using KDE 3.0 and a linux kernel 2.4.18. I am using SuSE 8.0 pretty much out of the package. I have upgraded as much as the automatic update with YaST Control Center does update. I think I have updated some additional packages here and there, I can't remember for sure which ones though.
I'm using the default window manager for KDE which seems to be sawfish. karanta@hyperion:~> rpm -q sawfish sawfish-1.0.1-87
KDE is version 3.0.5 and:
akaranta@hyperion:~> uname -a Linux hyperion 2.4.18-4GB #1 Wed Mar 27 13:57:05 UTC 2002 i686 unknown
KDE uses the kwin window manager. GNOME can use many different window managers, of which Sawfish is one. When you log-in, what "session type" do you choose?
Can you attach a screenshot of Eclipse immediately after it has started? Created attachment 13402 A screenshot of Eclipse 3.0 right after it has started Ok, I attached the screenshot.
When I log in, I choose KDE as session type.
I haven't changed my window manager. I assumed I am using sawfish, as when I open SuSE Menu --> System --> WM --> Window Manager I get a window titled "Control Center" opened under Desktop --> Window Manager and on the right it has the following list with the word current in brackets after sawfish:
Sawfish (current) twm Window Maker
But now that I looked closer, it seems to be the Gnome Control Center. Sorry, my mistake...
This is definitely Motif, and it seems from the user has said that they are using KDE/kwin.
Could you please the hs_err_pid*.log files from the crashes? These will likely be located in the Eclipse installation directory itself, but might be in your home directory.
Doing something like "find ~ -name 'hs_err_pid*.log'" might help you find them. Created attachment 13497 Crash error log Created attachment 13498 Another error log Created attachment 13499 Yet another error log
These error logs seem to contain the same reason. There's more of these, but I think they will show nothing new. If you want more, please ask. The crash is in native code. Grant, if this is a duplicate of bug 47549 please mark it as such.

Bug.Summery: Simple Console Filtering
Bug.WithStack:
Request a feature so that you can filter the consoles output to lines containing a specific phrase. This is useful for debugging when there is a lot of output.
Many times developers prefix a specific output line, e.g. "LASTNAME: Smith"
So if you could filter for "LASTNAME:" would be great.
But often you need to see just more than one particular phrase, because data is related to each other. So the filter ability should be able to filter to lines containing any of a list of Strings.
e.g. filter for "LASTNAME:" and "FIRSTNAME:" Also, should be able to save these Filter sets for reuse later.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 40705 ***
Bug.WithOutStack:
Request a feature so that you can filter the consoles output to lines containing a specific phrase. This is useful for debugging when there is a lot of output.
