!ENTRY org.eclipse.team.cvs.core 4 -10 Aug 25, 2004 11:34:57.530 !MESSAGE The server reported an error while performing the "cvs update" command. !SUBENTRY 1 org.eclipse.team.cvs.core 4 -14 Aug 25, 2004 11:34:57.530 !MESSAGE cvs_sudo_test: cvs server: failed to create lock directory for `/cm/cvsstst/cvs_sudo_test/CVSROOT' (/cm/cvsstst/cvs_sudo_test/CVSROOT/#cvs.lock): Permission denied !SUBENTRY 1 org.eclipse.team.cvs.core 4 -14 Aug 25, 2004 11:34:57.530 !MESSAGE cvs_sudo_test: cvs server: failed to obtain dir lock in repository `/cm/cvsstst/cvs_sudo_test/CVSROOT' !SUBENTRY 1 org.eclipse.team.cvs.core 4 -14 Aug 25, 2004 11:34:57.530 !MESSAGE cvs_sudo_test: cvs [server aborted]: read lock failed - giving up There is something quite odd about the trac you have provided. You are checking out the module "eigener_test" and the checkout seems to have gone well. However, the update you are doing seems to be on a project that contain "eigener_test" asw a subdirectory. Is this correct? Can you give me the details of the operatios you performed so I can match them to the trace (i.e. the trace doesn't contain that information). It's right what you said. The user check out some modules from a repository to a project (here eigener_test from repository cvs_sudo_test in project cvs_sudo_test). After some time they want to make an update of all the modules checked out, so they make team update of the project, that means update all the modules included in the project (here update project cvs_sudo_test - and therefore update module eigener_test). And how did they create the project "cvs_sudo_test"? Create new project (file - new - project) - simple project - name the project - finish. Sorry, I should have stated my question better. How did the project get created and shared with the repository root (as it appears to be from the trace). It would be easiest if you gave me a complete explanation of all the steps that you take to cause the problem to happen and provide as much detail as possible. I could then match this up with the trace to determine where the problem is. There are only a few steps
cvs-view: - add a new cvs-repository (/cm/cvsstst/cvs_sudo_test) resource-view: - create a simple project (cvs_sudo_test) in my tests the project is named as the repository cvs-view: - expand the head (from cvs_sudo_test) - mark a module (eigener_test) - check out as - in an existing project this is checkout /cm/cvsstst/cvs_sudo_test/eigener_test in project cvs_sudo_test) resource-view: - mark project cvs_sudo_test - team update that's all
OK, I've figured out what is going wrong. The repository you are using is configured to provide a top level admin directory (i.e. the line "TopLevelAdmin=yes" appears in your CVSROOT/config file). When you do a checkout of the "eigener_test" module into the simple project, Eclipse is receiving the top level admin directory and assigning it to the parent project. Eclipse CVS does ignore the top-level-admin when it is checking out a project (i.e. when the admin directory is the root of the repository). However, it does not when the top-level-admin folder is a project or subfolder.
It's not clear to me what, if anything, we want to do here. The implication of configuring a repository to use topLevelAdmin is that the users will be able to perform an update on multiple projects but will not be able to use the -d option to fetch the absent directories. The current workarounds are to turn off topLevelAdmins, turn off fetch absent directories for the project or only perform updates on the subfolder that was checked out. Alternatively, the user could define a module in the CVSROOT/modules file that created a project that had the proper structure.
The problem would be lessened if the update command itself allowed the user to decide whether to fetch absent directories or not. I'm a litle late, but last week I wasn't here. First thank you for your answer. Now I need to discuss the situation here. For this, please can you tell me the reason why eclipse version 3... handles the situation in another way as version 2.1.x. Perhaps this will help us to find the right solution. Improvments were made to CVS checkout in 3.0. Unfortunately, these improvements had the unforseen consequences you are experiencing.

Bug.Summery: [jres] Changes to JREs lost if Preferences page is active

Lines.Line: 1. Go to Window > Preferences.
2. Go to the Java > Installed JREs preference page.
3. Go to another preference page that will make changes to the JREs.
4. Make some changes and click Ok. (Underlying page will make changes to one
or more IVMInstalls and call JavaRuntime.saveVMConfiguration()).
5. Reopen preferences - the IVMInstall changes are lost.

Bug.WithStack:
If the Java > Installed JREs preference page is active, any changes made by other preference pages to the JREs are lost even if no changes were made to the Installed JREs page. This scenario can occur when higher level tools need to make changes to JREs. For example, a preference page for a Java server runtime might provide a setting to change where the server is installed - if the server contains it's own JRE, then the underlying IVMInstall location should also be changed.
To reproduce, the scenario would be:
1. Go to Window > Preferences. 2. Go to the Java > Installed JREs preference page. 3. Go to another preference page that will make changes to the JREs. 4. Make some changes and click Ok. (Underlying page will make changes to one or more IVMInstalls and call JavaRuntime.saveVMConfiguration()). 5. Reopen preferences - the IVMInstall changes are lost.
Doing the same thing without step 2 will allow the changes to apply correctly. The #performOK() method is called on the page even if no changes were made. We likely need to do two things:
(1) only save changes if changes were made (2) look to see if someone else made changes to the installed VMs (i.e. when the page is opened, it should note the state. If changes were made on the page, but when we go to save, the original state is no longer the same, then saving should abort/report error?). We may be able to use the "IVMInstallChangedListener" mechanism to note there were changes, and if the changes are compatible with the changes we are going to make.
deferred As of now 'LATER' and 'REMIND' resolutions are no longer supported. Please reopen this bug if it is still valid for you.

Stacktrace.Reason: Operation only supported in JLS2 AST

Lines.Line: 1) create method mymethod()
2) create method mymethod() in enclosing class (Main in the example below).

Bug.WithStack:
I input in the editor a call to a non-existing function in a inner class. Code assist offers me 2 possibilities: 1) create method mymethod() 2) create method mymethod() in enclosing class (Main in the example below).
2nd choice doesn't work. It does nothing
class Main { class Nested { void a() { mymethod(); } } } It also fails in non-nested scenarios. Steps to reproduce:
Include a call to a non-existant function. Call code assist and select the correction: created method. Nothing is done. what build are you using? I can't reproduce this with 3.0 I think you are refereing to quick fix, not code assist.
For the given example the only quick fix I get is 'create method'. Note that 'create methid in enclosing class' is only available for methods in anonymous classes.
can you also check the .log file? Also have a look if something is shown in the status line.
Sorry, it was quick fix (Ctrl+1). I'm using Eclipse 3.0 final. No message in the status line. If the method to be created resides in another class, Eclipse correctly switches to that editor, but no new method is appended to the source code.

Bug.Summery: [Import/Export] Import... from file system should skip backup files
Bug.WithStack:
Using Eclipse 3.0GA I did: * Create a project to import stuff into. * File -> Import... -> File system * Choose any directory containing backup files (file names ending in ~).
Current behaviour: The pane listing available files includes backup files. The Filter Types... button makes it possible to include files by type, but excluding backup files isn't possible AFAICT.
Expected behaviour: Backup files should be filtered out by default. ~ is not always a backup file but it might be useful to filter directory types as well as file types. Just out of curiosity, can you come up with an example of when a file would be named something ending in ~ but without being a backup file?
Not offhand but we could not assume that someone would not choose to use that as a prefix for something in thier product - as a framework we have to be pretty confident of the meaning of something to force everyone to use it. Sounds reasonable, even though I'd find it pretty stupid to use foo~ for naming something other than a backup. Stranger things have happened.
Just to be sure that it was a typo and not a mis-understanding btw, when you said "prefix", you really meant "suffix", right?
A backup file is a file named "whatever~", i.e. one whose name *ends* in "~".
Actually the answer is "both" - as a framework we can't make this decision - I have seen prodicts that use the ~ as a prefix or a suffix. There's a related issue: On the Mac, every file has an associated metadata file that begins with ".". I'd like to see these hidden as well.
The problem is, the meaning of these files -- both metadata files and backup files -- is not specific to the platform you are running on, but is actually specific to the platform/tool that was used to create the file. Since we can't detect this, there's no way we can decide when it is appropriate to filter them out.
Given that we are using the platform dialogs, we also don't have an opportunity to add a "show hidden" button (or the like) to them, so there doesn't seem to be any simple way to provide this behavior, except perhaps adding a global preference something like the "Java -> Appearance -> Type Filters" preference. (/em gags.)
Having said that, if someone wants to take a stab at fixing this, we can definitely discuss the issues. For now, marking as WONTFIX.

Sounds reasonable, even though I'd find it pretty stupid to use foo~ for naming something other than a backup. Stranger things have happened.
Just to be sure that it was a typo and not a mis-understanding btw, when you said "prefix", you really meant "suffix", right?
A backup file is a file named "whatever~", i.e. one whose name *ends* in "~".
Actually the answer is "both" - as a framework we can't make this decision - I have seen prodicts that use the ~ as a prefix or a suffix. There's a related issue: On the Mac, every file has an associated metadata file that begins with ".". I'd like to see these hidden as well.
The problem is, the meaning of these files -- both metadata files and backup files -- is not specific to the platform you are running on, but is actually specific to the platform/tool that was used to create the file. Since we can't detect this, there's no way we can decide when it is appropriate to filter them out.
Given that we are using the platform dialogs, we also don't have an opportunity to add a "show hidden" button (or the like) to them, so there doesn't seem to be any simple way to provide this behavior, except perhaps adding a global preference something like the "Java -> Appearance -> Type Filters" preference. (/em gags.)
Having said that, if someone wants to take a stab at fixing this, we can definitely discuss the issues. For now, marking as WONTFIX.

Bug.Summery: [content assist] Allow to configure what's shown in content assistant
Bug.WithStack:
In the 3.0, the code completion provides method stubs proposal, but also getter and setters (http://download.eclipse.org/downloads/drops/R-3.0-200406251208/eclipse-news-part4-R3.html ; "Create getters and setters with code assist"). I would like to disable these proposals, for example in code assist preferences :) Is it all method subs and getter/setters or do you also want to hide code templates?
Do you want to enable them per category or all at once?
Disabling by category would be fine, but, in my case, disabling all at once is sufficient.
I want to keep code template. Indeed, I have a custom method template, and when I call it (the cursor is in a class, but out of method context), the code completion proposes my custom template AND the corresponding method stub. I have then to select the template. As I am a lazy boy, if the method stub is not activated, my custom would be applied directly :)
An intermediate solution would be to order completion proposals, not only in alphabetical order, with for example, code templates before method stub/getter/setter. Martin, please comment as well (especially explain the current ordering).
the ordering for the method stubs is defined by jdt.core (relevance value), template relevance is defined by us
see bug 88213 for better sorting of sub proposals.
While the stubs currently can't be disabled separately, we have introduced content assist categories that may be disabled via the user preferences. Also, the fact that stubs and override proposals are never auto-inserted make them less annoying.
Marking as fixed.

Bug.Summery: [projection][key binding] Key bindings for folding not easily accessible on notebooks
Bug.WithStack:
3.0
From bug 64347:
Key bindings are on the numpad which is not available (or difficult to access with additional modifier key) on notebooks. It's also counter-intuitive to have key bindings on the numpad different from those on the main keyboard. No plans to change this.

3.0

Bug.Summery: Project References do not reflect build path projects
Bug.WithStack:
In the project properties, adding a project in Java Build Project no longer adds a Project Reference entry. This is a shame since our ant build uses this as dependancy information.
Rob We are now setting project dynamic references, instead of static ones.
These should be visible still through API: IProject.getReferencedProjects() but no longer persisted in .project file, as no longer necessary. Dynamic project references allow to compute classpath dynamically, and not resulting in outgoing changes on .project file as a side-effect.
Please reopen if you found a case where the above API did not work correctly, and then provide steps to reproduce.
Bug.WithOutStack:
In the project properties, adding a project in Java Build Project no longer adds a Project Reference entry. This is a shame since our ant build uses this as dependancy information.
Rob We are now setting project dynamic references, instead of static ones.
These should be visible still through API: IProject.getReferencedProjects() but no longer persisted in .project file, as no longer necessary. Dynamic project references allow to compute classpath dynamically, and not resulting in outgoing changes on .project file as a side-effect.
Please reopen if you found a case where the above API did not work correctly, and then provide steps to reproduce.
